sentence: At this point in Twitter’s (TWTR) lifecycle, it's fair to say it will never be Facebook (FB).
And for a great portion of investors, that has been enough to stay away from the embattled social media company.
But to Twitter’s credit, the company’s 2017 campaign — during which its shares have soared more some 53% to new 52-week highs — shows that it will never be MySpace, either.
And that, too, could be enough to sway new investors to buy into CEO Jack Dorsey’s long-term vision — something Wall Street analysts have begun to do.

Twitter stock has been on fire, soaring some 16% in the past five days, including an 11% surge on Monday, thanks to a major endorsement from J.P. Morgan analyst Doug Anmuth, who named Twitter among the firm's best stock ideas for 2018.
Investors wasted no time buying into the idea that Twitter’s worst days are behind it.
The prospects of better monetization, combined with improving investor sentiment has turned Twitter into a hot commodity.
Take a look at the chart, courtesy of YCharts.
Anmuth upgraded the stock to an Overweight rating and bumped his 12-month price target to $27 from $20.
This suggests potential stock returns of more than 21% from Friday’s closing price of $22.23.

"We believe both the TWTR story and financial results will strengthen over the next year as the company continues to build on its differentiated value proposition for users & returns to revenue growth," Anmuth wrote in his note Monday, according to CNBC.
The company’s improved live-streaming capabilities is one of several factors Anmuth sees as increasing Twitter’s growth, including an expected 10% increase in daily active user growth next year.
More importantly, he now expects the company to be profitable in 2018, which would mark a significant leap in the company’s investment profile.
Profits have escaped Twitter, despite the company boasting some 300 million users.
It reported a 4% decline in revenue in the third quarter.
But there’s more to the story, according to Anmuth.

"We believe increasing traction with both users and advertisers will drive upside to 2018 consensus (we are 4 percent above on revenue & 15 percent on EBITDA) and investor sentiment around TWTR remains mixed."
The idea that it is ready to turn the corner should excite current investors who have waited almost three years for the shares to break out.
The stock currently trading just 7% below Anmuth’s target of $27, meaning Twitter, which still has an average Street target of $19, is likely to see a few more upgrades.
Once the subject of numerous M&A speculation involving the likes of Salesforce.com (CRM) and Disney (DIS), Twitter may find itself back in the discussion.
But will it price itself out of consideration?
For current investors, that’s a great problem to have.
The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
